DOC.HEAD: Much of Nation in Deep Freeze
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures were in the single digits throughout the nation early today, as an arctic cold front extended as far south as Florida. Snow blanketed parts of the Carolinas and Jacksonville, Fla., while other parts of the South also shivered under unusually low temperatures. Temperatures in Tennessee plunged to 0 in Memphis and 6 below in Nashville, and in Georgia a sheet of ice and up to 2 inches of snow covered the state's Golden Isles, normally a holiday haven of winter golf among the palm trees. Temperatures fell to 6 below in Louisville. The deep freeze continued in the Northeast, with temperatures today dropping to 3 degrees in Portland, Maine, 5 in Boston and 8 in New York. Snow fell amid 0 degree temperatures in Pittsburgh. In the Midwest, temperatures dropped to 20 below in Des Moines, Ill., and Kansas City, Mo. Snow also fell today in Michigan and Ohio. More than 125 cities reported record low temperatures for the date Friday, with the town of Rochford in the Black Hills of western South Dakota reporting a low of 60 degrees below 0. Temperatures dipped to 47 below in Montana at Broadus and Hardin. Records lows Friday included Pittsburgh at 12 below; Tulsa 6 below; Oklahoma City at 4 below; Denver at 18 below, and Scottsbluff, Neb., at 42 below. A low of 23 degrees below zero made it the coldest day ever in Kansas City, Mo. In parts of central Montana, a warm front caused a rapid rise in Temperatures Friday. Cutbank went from a morning low of 34 below to an afternoon high of 40. Fair skies and seasonable temperatures prevailed in the West Friday. Temperatures warmed into the 60s and 70s in southern Arizona and even into the 80s in parts of Southern California. The high for the nation today was 81 degrees in California at Escondido, Fallbrook and Spring Valley.
